title: Derek Gardner
text:
Derek George Montague Gardner (13 February 1914 – 11 February 2007) was an <a href="England">English</a> <a href="painting">painter</a>. After a career as a <a href="civil%20engineering">civil engineer</a> before and after serving in the <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> in the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a>, he became widely recognised as one of the leading English painters of marine subjects.
Early life.
Gardner was born in <a href="Buckinghamshire">Buckinghamshire</a>. His father was a <a href="civil%20engineering">civil engineer</a> who worked for the <a href="Great%20Central%20Railway">Great Central Railway</a> in the docks at <a href="Grimsby">Grimsby</a> and became chief engineer of the <a href="Port%20of%20Glasgow">Port of Glasgow</a> in 1928, and Gardner developed a love of ships.
He was educated at <a href="Oundle%20School">Oundle School</a>, where he won a prize for his drawing. He left school in 1931, and trained as a civil engineer in <a href="Glasgow">Glasgow</a> with the <a href="London%20Midland%20%26amp%3B%20Scottish%20Railway">London Midland & Scottish Railway</a>. He later joined <a href="Sir%20William%20Arrol%20%26amp%3B%20Co.">Sir William Arrol & Co.</a> He joined the <a href="Royal%20Naval%20Volunteer%20Reserve">RNVR</a> as a 20-year-old <a href="midshipman">midshipman</a>, and took up painting <a href="watercolour">watercolour</a>s of warships. He became a docks engineer at <a href="North%20Shields">North Shields</a> in 1938.
Second World War.
Gardner was called up in August 1939, shortly after the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a> broke out, and served as anti-submarine officer on the <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> <a href="destroyer">destroyer</a> <a href="HMS%20Broke%20%28D83%29">HMS "Broke"</a>. His ship escorted convoys in the <a href="Atlantic">Atlantic</a> and <a href="Arctic%20Ocean">Arctic Ocean</a>s, and was then posted to the <a href="Mediterranean">Mediterranean</a> to support the <a href="Operation%20Torch">Operation Torch</a> landings in <a href="North%20Africa">North Africa</a>.
He joined <a href="Operation%20Terminal">Operation Terminal</a>, the storming of <a href="Algiers">Algiers</a> harbour in November 1942. The destroyers HMS "Broke" and <a href="HMS%20Malcolm%20%28D19%29">HMS "Malcolm"</a> were tasked with securing the port facilities and power station at Algiers. "Malcolm" came under fire and was forced to withdraw with engine damage, but "Broke" rammed through a boom protecting the harbour and disembarked its shore party. "Broke" then also came under heavy fire from <a href="Vichy%20French">Vichy French</a> forces and was forced to withdraw. "Broke" sank the next day while heading for <a href="Gibraltar">Gibraltar</a>. Her crew, including Gardner, were rescued by the destroyer <a href="HMS%20Zetland%20%28L59%29">HMS "Zetland"</a> and returned to Algiers, now captured by the Allies, before returning to England on a Dutch liner. The convoy was attacked by a submarine: the <a href="escort%20carrier">escort carrier</a> immediately ahead, , was <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>ed and sank. Gardner had been injured in Algiers, and was rendered <a href="deaf">deaf</a> in one ear. He was later <a href="mentioned%20in%20dispatches">mentioned in dispatches</a> for his actions.
He joined the destroyer <a href="HMS%20Highlander%20%28H44%29">HMS "Highlander"</a> in 1943, serving again in the Atlantic, but his deafness then forced him to serve on land rather than at sea. He was promoted to <a href="lieutenant%20commander">lieutenant commander</a> and served on the staff of Admiral Sir <a href="Max%20Horton">Max Horton</a>, commander of the <a href="Western%20Approaches">Western Approaches</a> based in <a href="Liverpool">Liverpool</a>. By the end of the war, he was an acting <a href="commander">commander</a>, serving as Assistant Chief Staff Officer Ceylon, based in <a href="Colombo">Colombo</a>. He was <a href="demobilised">demobilised</a> in 1946.
He was awarded the <a href="Volunteer%20Reserve%20Decoration">Volunteer Reserve Decoration</a> (VRD).
Post-war career.
Gardner joined the <a href="Colonial%20Service">Colonial Service</a> after the war, serving in <a href="Kenya">Kenya</a> from 1951. He met his wife, Mary, at a dance in <a href="Mombasa">Mombasa</a>. He then worked as an engineer in west Kenya, living in <a href="Kisumu">Kisumu</a> beside <a href="Lake%20Victoria">Lake Victoria</a>, before moving to <a href="Nakuru">Nakuru</a>, where he painted oils, watercolours and pastels of local scenes, such as flamingos on a nearby soda lake.
He caught <a href="tick">tick</a> <a href="typhus">typhus</a>, and became deaf in both ears. He returned to England with his family in 1963, and retired to <a href="Dorset">Dorset</a>. He turned to painting maritime subjects. His detailed paintings found a ready market, and he held several exhibitions in London. He is best known for his paintings of warships from the <a href="Napoleonic%20Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a>, and paintings of <a href="clipper">clipper</a>s from later in the 19th century.
An exhibition of his work at <a href="Messum%27s">Messum's</a> gallery in <a href="Mayfair">Mayfair</a> in October 2005, the bicentenary of the <a href="Battle%20of%20Trafalgar">Battle of Trafalgar</a>, included paintings of every ship in which <a href="Horatio%20Nelson%2C%201st%20Viscount%20Nelson">Nelson</a> had served. A book of the paintings, "Nelson's Ships: A Trafalgar Tribute".
He was a Fellow of the <a href="Institution%20of%20Civil%20Engineers">Institution of Civil Engineers</a>, and also a member of the <a href="Royal%20Society%20of%20Marine%20Artists">Royal Society of Marine Artists</a>.
He was survived by his wife, and their son and daughter.
